Homomorphisms between A-modules, also referred to as A-homomorphisms, are defined just as in the context of vector spaces.
The length l_A(M) of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers l such that there is a chain of submodules 0 subsetneq M_1 subsetneq M_2 subsetneq ... subsetneq M_l = M of length l.
Does the concept of a/an A-homomorphism need to be defined for a definition of a/an Length of an A-module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the length of an A-module involves the existence of chains of submodules within the module itself. This definition focuses on the structure of submodules and their hierarchical arrangement up to the module M. It does not inherently require the concept of homomorphisms between different A-modules, as it is concerned solely with the internal structure of a single A-module and the existence of a sequence of nested submodules.

On the other hand, the concept of an A-homomorphism pertains to mappings between different A-modules that preserve the module structure. This concept is crucial when discussing functions or transformations between modules but does not directly influence the definition or understanding of the length of a single A-module, which is based on its internal submodule structure.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of the length of an A-module do not require the concept of an A-homomorphism, as these two concepts operate on different aspects of module theory.
